title: Thermal acclimation increases heat tolerance of the scleractinian coral Acropora pruinosa

abstract: Field ecological observations indicate that scleractinian coral exposed to early thermal stress are likely to develop higher tolerance to subsequent heat stress. The causes of this phenomenon, however, remain enigmatic. To unravel the mechanisms underlying the increased heat tolerance, we applied different thermal treatments to the scleractinian coral Acropora pruinosa and studied the resulting differences in appearance, physiological index, Symbiodiniaceae and bacterial communities, and transcriptome response. We found that early heat stress improved the thermal tolerance of the coral holobiont. After thermal acclimation, the community structure and symbiotic bacterial diversity in the microbiota were reorganized, whereas those of Symbiodiniaceae remained stable. RNA-seq analysis revealed that the downregulated coral host genes were mainly involved in pathways relating to metabolism, particularly the nitrogen metabolism pathway. This indicates that thermal acclimation led to decrease in the metabolism level in the coral host, which might be a self-protection mechanism. We suggest that thermal acclimation may increase scleractinian coral thermal tolerance by slowing host metabolism, altering the dominant bacterial population, and increasing bacterial diversity. This study offers new insights into the adaptive potential of scleractinian coral to heat stress from global warming.

abstract.text: Field ecological observations indicate that scleractinian coral exposed to early thermal stress are likely to develop higher tolerance to subsequent heat stress. The causes of this phenomenon, however, remain enigmatic. To unravel the mechanisms underlying the increased heat tolerance, we applied different thermal treatments to the scleractinian coral Acropora pruinosa and studied the resulting differences in appearance, physiological index, Symbiodiniaceae and bacterial communities, and transcriptome response. We found that early heat stress improved the thermal tolerance of the coral holobiont. After thermal acclimation, the community structure and symbiotic bacterial diversity in the microbiota were reorganized, whereas those of Symbiodiniaceae remained stable. RNA-seq analysis revealed that the downregulated coral host genes were mainly involved in pathways relating to metabolism, particularly the nitrogen metabolism pathway. This indicates that thermal acclimation led to decrease in the metabolism level in the coral host, which might be a self-protection mechanism. We suggest that thermal acclimation may increase scleractinian coral thermal tolerance by slowing host metabolism, altering the dominant bacterial population, and increasing bacterial diversity. This study offers new insights into the adaptive potential of scleractinian coral to heat stress from global warming.

body_text.text: • Tropical coral reefs are in rapid decline in the Anthropocene. • Early heat stress improves thermal tolerance of the coral holobiont. • Acclimation is an outcome of interdependent responses of the holobiont components. • Thermal acclimation led to a decrease in the metabolic level of the coral host. • Microbial diversity is potentially involved in coral adaptability.
body_text.section: H I G H L I G H T S

body_text.text: a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
body_text.section: G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T

body_text.text: Scleractinian coral form the biological and physical framework for a large, diverse marine ecosystem in oligotrophic oceans (Roth and Deheyn, 2013) . However, tropical coral reefs are in a rapid decline in the Anthropocene (Hughes et al., 2018; Hughes et al., 2017a Hughes et al., , 2017b Yu, 2012) . Indeed, coral reefs are projected to decline by 70-90% relative to their current abundance by midcentury (Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2018; Van Hooidonk et al., 2016) , with more severe effects for especially sensitive corals such as Acropora (Loya et al., 2001) . Fortunately, in contrast to these dire predictions, evidence for coral adaptability to thermal stress suggests that bleaching thresholds may increase in response to ocean warming and can substantially increase future survival (Barshis et al., 2013; Bay et al., 2017; Hughes et al., 2003; Safaie et al., 2018; Wright et al., 2019) . For example, it has been reported that the onset of coral bleaching in the last decade has occurred at significantly higher sea surface temperatures (SSTs) (~0.5°C) than in the previous decade, and the remaining coral populations have higher thermal thresholds for bleaching (Sully et al., 2019) . The global coral bleaching event caused by El Niño in 2015-2016 is considered the longest and most widespread global coral bleaching event (Hughes et al., 2017a (Hughes et al., , 2017b Lough et al., 2018) . However, in some areas, coral bleaching did not occur as severely as expected, and total coral coverage did not decrease significantly (Harrison et al., 2019; Kirk et al., 2018) . At the same time, some studies have found that coral bleaching is less common in localities with high variance in SST anomalies (Barker, 2018; Barshis et al., 2018; Jury and Toonen, 2019; Oliver and Palumbi, 2011; Sully et al., 2019; Thomas et al., 2018) . Furthermore, similar studies carried out in the laboratory have found that acclimated coral have more effective photoprotective mechanisms (Middlebrook et al., 2008) . Although it has been observed in different regions of the world, the underlying molecular mechanisms and key players that contribute to this ecological phenomenon are unknown. Therefore, it is crucial to study the potential mechanism underlying improved heat tolerance of scleractinian coral and its implications for coral reef conservation and management.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Of course, not all coral species will respond in the same way to ocean warming. Bleaching susceptibility also varies according to coral species, location, thermal history, environmental acclimation capability, and Symbiodiniaceae genotype (Berkelmans and Van Oppen, 2006; Liang et al., 2017; Loya et al., 2001; Qin et al., 2019; Thompson and Van Woesik, 2009) . It has been widely recognized that scleractinian corals are composed of several symbiotic organisms, namely, the cnidarian host, Symbiodiniaceae, and bacterial community (Brener-Raffalli et al., 2018) . These partners are involved in stable symbiosis that effectively constitutes the holobiont (Brener-Raffalli et al., 2018) . Although recent studies have shown that the coral host (Baird et al., 2009; Kenkel et al., 2013; Quigley et al., 2019) , Symbiodiniaceae (Chen et al., 2019; Howe-Kerr et al., 2019; Lin et al., 2019; Qin et al., 2019) , and symbiotic bacteria (Liang et al., 2017; Pollock et al., 2019; Ziegler et al., 2017a Ziegler et al., , 2017b are separately involved in the coral heat stress response. Unfortunately, only a limited number of studies have examined the effects of thermal acclimation on the thermal tolerance of scleractinian coral, of which most studies examine a single partner, resulting in highly varied findings. For example, it has been reported that the evolution of climate change tolerance depends on the standing genetic variation (Bay and Palumbi, 2014; Kirk et al., 2018) and adaptive plasticity in the expression of environmental stress response (ESR) genes (Kenkel and Matz, 2016; Palumbi et al., 2014) , rather than gene expression and community changes in Symbiodiniaceae and bacteria (Brener-Raffalli et al., 2018) . However, other research has shown that corals appear to be more adequately adapted to thermal extremes by retaining chlorophyll concentrations during frequent heat pulses, which was associating with thermally tolerant endosymbionts, upregulated gene expression associated with heat acclimation, and possession of a potentially advantageous microbiome composition (Barker, 2018) . Clearly, the processes and pathways that could facilitate rapid adaptive responses in scleractinian coral are diverse, and understanding of their underlying molecular mechanisms is still in its infancy (Kenkel et al., 2013) . Hence, an integrated approach for analysing the response process and interaction of each symbiotic protagonist is needed to study the coral adaptive response to environmental stress.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In the current study, we aimed to elucidate the impact of early acute heat stress on the response of the scleractinian coral to heat stress by employing a holistic approach. Acropora pruinosa colonies are widely distributed in the tropical and subtropical areas of the Indian and Pacific Oceans and are especially sensitive to environmental stress, making their relative ability to acclimate or adapt extremely important to the future of coral reef ecosystems as climate change continues. Further, A. pruinosa has been well studied both in situ and in laboratory settings. We investigated the effect of early exposure of A. pruinosa to elevated temperature through next-generation sequencing, as well as physiological and cytological experimental methods. We tested the hypotheses that (1) early acute heat stress improves the thermal tolerance of the scleractinian coral A. pruinosa, and (2) coral host, Symbiodiniaceae, and symbiotic bacteria contribute to the coral holobiont's higher tolerance in the process of thermal acclimation. We examined the physiological state, antioxidant enzymes activity, Symbiodiniaceae density, chlorophyll fluorescence, Symbiodiniaceae and bacterial communities, and differentially expressed genes of coral hosts and Symbiodiniaceae to illustrate the cytological, physiological and molecular response mechanisms associated with increased heat tolerance. By characterising the acclimation of the three components of the A. pruinosa holobiont, we obtained a deep insight into the acclimation process, improving our understanding of the general heat stress, and identifying the potential molecular regulation mechanisms involved in the survival or death of the scleractinian coral. Addressing these issues is necessary to evaluate the coevolution potential of coral and symbionts, which, in turn, is essential for the modelling rates and spatial patterns of coral adaptation to global warming.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A. pruinosa was collected from Weizhou Island, Beibu Gulf, China, and grown at the Coral Reef Research Center, Guangxi University. Clones of the same A. pruinosa isolate were used to avoid potential individual variability and genetic background effects. Small fragments were mounted onto numbered holders with aquascaping glue (iSTA), and immediately transferred to a 300-L aquarium illuminated with an aquarium light (250 W metal halogen lamp and 4 T5HO), as its light spectrum is similar to that of natural light (12 h light: 12 h dark cycle). Coral nubbins were acclimated at 26°C for 14 days prior to analysis. The described lighting and aquarium conditions were maintained throughout the experiment. A. pruinosa were fed freshly hatched nauplii of Artemia salina (brine shrimp) twice weekly.
body_text.section: Coral material and thermal tolerance assay

body_text.text: Three groups were established: control (26°C for 14 days), unacclimated (33°C for 3 days), and acclimated (acclimated at 31°C for 2 days with a 14-day recovery period at 26°C, followed by treatment at 33°C for 3 days). Corals were sampled five times with six biological repeats every time, as follows: coral nubbins from the control group on the fourteenth day (C); coral nubbins from the acclimated group after 2 days at 31°C (A); coral nubbins from the acclimated group after the 14-day recovery (RA); coral nubbins from the unacclimated group after 3 days at 33°C (HS); coral nubbins from RA subsequently exposed to 33°C for 3 days (RAHS). In all experiments, the temperature was elevated at a rate of 1°C per 12 h. Sampling time point details are shown in Table S1 . After heat treatment, each sample was photographed and immediately stored in liquid nitrogen for future Symbiodiniaceae clade type, bacterial community, and transcriptome analysis. In order to ensure the reliability of data analysis, three biological repeats were from each group were utilised in Symbiodiniaceae community, bacteria community, and coral transcriptome analyses.
body_text.section: Coral material and thermal tolerance assay

body_text.text: Symbiodiniaceae density was expressed as a multiple of 10 6 cells cm −2 surface area of living tissue (Drew, 1972; Nakamura et al., 2003) . After each treatment, pieces of coral were removed using a recirculating Waterpik containing filtered seawater (0.22 μm) (Higuchi et al., 2008) . Supernatants were used for analyses of antioxidant enzyme activities (Tang et al., 2018) .
body_text.section: Symbiodiniaceae density, chlorophyll fluorescence, and antioxidant enzyme activities

body_text.text: Chlorophyll fluorescence was measured using a Diving-PAM underwater fluorometer (Walz Heinz GmbH, Effeltrich, Germany) after living coral nubbins were subjected to the dark for 20 min (Schreiber, 1986) . Fv/Fm is the maximum photochemical quantum yield of PS II, reflecting the intrinsic efficiency of energy conversion in the PS II reaction centre (Demmig and Björkman, 1987) .
body_text.section: Symbiodiniaceae density, chlorophyll fluorescence, and antioxidant enzyme activities

body_text.text: Superoxide dismutase (SOD) and catalase (CAT) activities were determined using commercial kits (Nanjing Jiancheng Bioengineering Institute, Nanjing, China), as previously described (Higuchi et al., 2015; Zhou et al., 2018) . The modified protein assay for total protein determination was performed using a BCA Protein Assay Kit (Sangon Biotech, Shanghai, China), according to the manufacturer's instructions. All data are presented as mean ± standard deviation. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) and multiple comparison test (Student-Newman-Keuls) were used to compare data from various conditions against the control. Differences were considered significant at p b .05.
body_text.section: Symbiodiniaceae density, chlorophyll fluorescence, and antioxidant enzyme activities

body_text.text: Genomic DNA was isolated from approximately 100-200 mg of frozen coral powder using a DNeasy Plant Mini Kit (QIAGEN, Hilden, Germany), according to the manufacturer's instructions. DNA concentration and purity were determined using a NanoDrop 2000 UV-vis spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Wilmington, VA, USA) (Desjardins and Conklin, 2010) . DNA quality was verified by 1% agarose gel electrophoresis. The ITS2 sequence was PCRamplified as previously described (Chen et al., 2019) . According to the manufacturer's instructions, all qualified amplification products were mixed in equimolar amounts and sequenced using an Illumina MiSeq instrument (Illumina, San Diego, CA, USA) in 2 × 300 bp paired-end mode. Sequencing was performed at Majorbio Biopharm Technology Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). The raw ITS2 sequencing datasets were deposited in the NCBI Sequence Read Archive (accession number PRJNA576197).
body_text.section: Symbiodiniaceae clade type determination

body_text.text: ITS2 sequence data analysis and operational taxonomic unit (OTU) data were analysed to evaluate the diversity and community composition of Symbiodiniaceae, as previously described (Chen et al., 2019) . All sequences were aligned with sequences deposited in the ITS2 database using BLASTn (https://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov), and previously described pipeline and parameters settings (Chen et al., 2019; Ziegler et al., 2017a Ziegler et al., , 2017b . To investigate ITS2 data at different resolution levels and facilitate comparison with previous denatured gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE) studies, we assessed the number of different ITS2 sequences that were present at a minimum cut-off N5% in at least one sample and filtering results (Ziegler et al., 2017a (Ziegler et al., , 2017b . ITS2 sequences were next subsampled using MOTHUR (https://www.mothur. org) (1000 reads per sample). Sequences with retention alignment lengths N90% were first clustered into an OTU, with further clustering at a 97% similarity threshold (Arif et al., 2014) . The most abundant OTU sequence without non-Symbiodiniaceae OTUs was used for statistical assessment of Symbiodiniaceae diversity and community composition.
body_text.section: Symbiodiniaceae clade type determination

body_text.text: Total genomic DNA of the coral samples was extracted using a TIANamp Marine Animals DNA Kit (Tiangen Biotech Co., Ltd., Beijing, China), according to the manufacturer's protocols. DNA quality was verified for further use. Bacterial 16S rRNA V3V4 was PCR-amplified using previously reported cycling conditions and primers 338F and 806R (Liang et al., 2017) . Purified amplicons were pooled in equimolar concentrations and paired-end sequenced (2 × 300 bp) using the Illumina MiSeq platform (Illumina, San Diego, USA), according to the standard protocols of Majorbio Bio-Pharm Technology Co. Ltd. Raw data were submitted to the NCBI SRA (accession number: PRJNA576303).
body_text.section: Microbial diversity analysis

body_text.text: Raw fastq files were demultiplexed, quality-filtered using the Trimmomatic read trimming tool, and merged using FLASH (http:// www.cbcb.umd.edu/software/flash) with the following criteria: (i) Reads were truncated at an average quality score b over a 50 bp sliding window. (ii) Primers were matched exactly allowing only 2 nucleotide mismatches, and reads containing ambiguous bases were removed. (iii) Sequences with overlap longer than 10 bp were merged according to their overlap sequence. After removing the chimeric sequences, OTUs were selected at a 97% similarity threshold. The remaining high-quality reads were used for taxonomic analysis. The taxonomy of each 16S rRNA gene sequence was analysed using the RDP Classifier against the Silva 16S rRNA database project (https://www.arb-silva. de), at a confidence threshold of 70%. OTU analysis of the sequences was performed using MOTHUR software, including Coverage, ACE estimator, and Shannon indices. Microbial community β-diversity was calculated based on the Bray-Curtis distance matrix (Zaneveld et al., 2016; McDevitt-Irwin et al., 2017) . Bray-Curtis distance matrices were constructed using rarefied OTU abundance tables and visualised by principal coordinate analysis (PCoA) and non-metric multidimensional scaling (NMDS). Differences in microbial communities were tested using analysis of similarities (ANOSIM) with 9999 permutations (Ziegler et al., 2017a (Ziegler et al., , 2017b . Microbiome metagenomes were imputed from the 16S rRNA sequences using the Phylogenetic Investigation of Communities by Reconstruction of Unobserved States (PICRUSt) (Langille et al., 2013) .
body_text.section: Microbial diversity analysis

body_text.text: Total RNA from the coral sample was extracted using Trizol reagent (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA) following the manufacturer's instructions. RNA quality was evaluated using the 2100 Bioanalyser (Agilent, Santa Clara, CA, USA) and quantified using an ND-2000 (NanoDrop Technologies). The RNA-seq transcriptome library was prepared using the TruSeqTM RNA sample preparation kit (Illumina) with 5 μg of total RNA, following the manufacturer's protocol. Briefly, messenger RNA was isolated according to the polyA selection method by oligo (dT) beads and then fragmented by using fragmentation buffer. Double-stranded cDNA was then synthesised using a SuperScript double-stranded cDNA synthesis kit (Invitrogen) with random hexamer primers (Illumina). The synthesised cDNA was then subjected to endrepair, phosphorylation, and 'A' base addition according to Illumina's library construction protocol. Libraries were size-selected for 200-300 bp cDNA target fragments on 2% low range ultra agarose followed by PCR amplification using Phusion DNA polymerase (New England Biolabs Inc., Ipswich, MA, USA) for 15 PCR cycles. After quantification using a TBS-380 fluorometer (Turner Biosystems, Sunnyvale, CA, USA) (Zhou et al., 2017a (Zhou et al., , 2017b , the paired-end RNA-seq library was sequenced using the HiSeq X Ten platform (2 × 150 bp read length, Illumina) (Zhou et al., 2017a (Zhou et al., , 2017b . Raw RNA-seq data are available from the NCBI SRA (BioProject: PRJNA576305).
body_text.section: RNA-seq analysis

body_text.text: Sequencing data from all samples were pooled for assembly. Raw paired-end reads were trimmed and their quality verified using SeqPrep and Sickle with default parameters. Clean data were than de novo assembled using Trinity (Grabherr et al., 2011). After assembly, annotations for the assembled unigenes were carried out via BLAST in six databases (Non-redundant (Nr), Swiss-prot, Pfam, Clusters of Orthologous Groups (COG), Gene Ontology (GO) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG)) (Camacho et al., 2009) . Sequences included members of the coral holobiont, i.e., symbionts, bacteria, fungi, and archaea. Based on previous studies, with minor modifications, and with reference to the reported genomes of corals Acropora digitifera, Stylophora pistillata, and Orbicella faveolata, and zooxanthella Symbiodiniaceae microadriaticum, the BLASTx pipeline was used to identify contigs that could be confidently assigned to either coral or symbiont transcriptomes (Bay and Palumbi, 2015; Mansour et al., 2016; Tang et al., 2018) . These transcripts were used in the subsequent read mapping and function annotation.
body_text.section: RNA-seq analysis

body_text.text: Transcript expression level was measured according to the fragments per kilobase of transcript per million mapped reads method (Qin et al., 2017) . RSEM (http://deweylab.github.io/RSEM) was used to quantify gene and isoform abundance. Differentially expressed genes (DEGs) between groups were identified (FDR b 0.05) using the obtained BAM files and DESeq2 software (Love et al., 2014) , and binned into two groups, i.e., significantly upregulated and significantly downregulated genes. The assembled unigenes were further annotated against the KEGG metabolic pathways database (Kanehisa and Goto, 2000) . KEGG annotation and enrichment analysis was performed using the Majorbio Cloud Platform. Over-representation analysis (ORA) using the Fisher's exact test (Benjamini-Hochberg adjusted pvalue b.05) was used for KEGG enrichment analysis (Backes et al., 2007; Désert et al., 2008) . The obtained p-value was corrected in order to control the probability or frequency of errors in the overall inference results using the Benjamini-Hochberg method for multiple test correction (Benjamini and Hochberg, 1995; Désert et al., 2008) .
body_text.section: RNA-seq analysis

body_text.text: Three randomly chosen RNA libraries per treatment group were used for qPCR validation of the RNA-seq results. A total of 10 DEGs (p b .01) between C and RA groups were validated using qPCR. Primer sets for real-time PCR analysis of the selected genes were designed based on each identified gene sequence of the transcriptome library (Table S2 ). Comparative CT method (2 −ΔΔCt algorithm) was used to analyse the expression levels of different genes (Livak and Schmittgen, 2001 ). All quantitative real-time PCRs were performed using the SYBR premix ExTaq (Takara Bio Inc., Kusatsu, Japan).
body_text.section: Validation of gene expression changes from RNA-seq by qPCR

body_text.text: Scleractinian corals, including A. pruinosa, are known to rapidly succumb to prolonged heat stress by developing tissue necrosis and sloughing (Schoepf et al., 2019) . No ramets with bleaching and disease were observed in the control and acclimated groups throughout the experiment; however, coral from the unacclimated group showed signs of tissue loss disease and bleaching after 33°C heat stress treatment (Fig. 1) . Meanwhile, Symbiodiniaceae density decreased significantly in group A after early heat stress. No significant differences in Symbiodiniaceae density were apparent in group RA compared with the control (p N .05) post recovery. The population density of Symbiodiniaceae in group HS was significantly lower at the final sampling point (day 39) than in group RAHS (p b .05) (Fig. 2) . Furthermore, we found that the chlorophyll fluorescence changed significantly under heat stress during the whole experiment (p b .05). The maximum Fig. 1 . Representative images of coral fragments from each treatment. quantum yield in A. pruinosa nubbins decreased after acute heat stress, reaching the lowest level in group HS, which was significantly lower than the maximum quantum yields in groups RA and RAHS (p b .05), however, there was no significant difference between groups C and RA (Fig. 2) . SOD and CAT activities increased after heat stress (Fig. 2) . Exposure to 31°C resulted in significantly increased CAT activity compared with that in the control (p b .05), although SOD activity was unchanged. At higher temperature (33°C), both SOD and CAT activities were significantly increased in group HS compared with the control (p b .05) and reached their highest levels, however, but no significant increase was apparent in group RAHS (p N .05). The activities of these two antioxidant enzymes were unchanged in RA compared with the control.
body_text.section: Coral bleaching and Symbiodiniaceae density dynamics

body_text.text: In the current study, 7,822,792 high-quality sequence reads representing 943,845 distinct ITS2 sequences were generated and analysed. Rarefaction curves indicated that the number of Symbiodiniaceae ITS2 sequences met the requirement for diversity analysis of Symbiodiniaceae subclades. For OTU-based analyses, these distinct ITS2 sequences clustered within Cladocopium (four OTUs) at a 97% similarity cut-off. Clade C1 (Cladocopium) was the most dominant subclade in each treatment group, with a mean relative abundance of 95.69%. Furthermore, no significant difference in OTU richness of Symbiodiniaceae was apparent between treatment groups (Welch's ttest, p N .05). Symbiodiniaceae community composition was determined by analysing OTUs with over 5% relative abundance in at least one ITS2 sequence sample. Analysis revealed that all samples were dominated by ITS2 sequences from clade C1 (Fig. S1) . Although minor differences in relative abundance for several subclades were observed, the main subclades in the algal community structure remained relatively stable. Accordingly, our results revealed no differences in community compositions of the dominant Symbiodiniaceae types in the different treatment groups.
body_text.section: Response of Symbiodiniaceae diversity and community to thermal acclimation

body_text.text: After subsampling for equal sequencing depth and clustering, 781,698 processed bacterial sequences were assigned to 6229 OTUs at a 97% similarity cut-off. The estimated sample coverage (Good's coverage) was approximately 99%, which indicated reliable accuracy and sequencing reproducibility. Of particular interest was the number of common and unique OTUs. Composition similarity and overlap of samples at the OTU level was illustrated by Venn diagram (Fig. S2) . Interestingly, OTU richness in group RAHS differed significantly from that in group HS (p b .05), while no significant difference was apparent between group RA and the control (Welch's t-test, p N .05, Fig. S2 ). Microbiota α-diversity was measured by Shannon index, with the highest microbiota diversity exhibited in group RAHS. Microbiota α-diversity was significantly higher in RA than in the control (Student's t-test, p b .01), which was significantly higher than in group HS (Student's ttest, p b .01) (Fig. S2) . Microbiome destabilisation, manifested as increased sample-to-sample variability, was quantified by microbiome β-diversity (Zaneveld et al., 2016) . We found that heat stress significantly increased β-diversity of the microbiome community structure (t-test, p b .01) (Fig. S2) . Microbiota β-diversity was significantly higher in group HS than in group RAHS (t-test, p b .01) (Fig. S2) . Microbial community similarity at the family level was evaluated using NMDS and PCoA based on Bray-Curtis distances. PCoA resulted in a 2-dimensional solution in which PC1 and PC2 accounted for 33.83% and 25.77% of the variation, respectively. Overall, results indicated a clear division between the coral compartments exposed to different treatments (Fig. S2) . NMDS analysis revealed that samples from the same treatment group clustered closely together, while those from different treatment groups were clustered further apart (stress: 0.062). Microbial community composition differed for different treatments (ANOSIM; Permutation number = 9999, R = 0.9896, p = .0001). In particular, group RA and the control exhibited low similarity. After the second high-temperature stress, group RAHS and the control were close and similar, while group HS displayed low similarity (Fig. S2) .
body_text.section: Changes in coral-associated bacterial communities during thermal acclimation

body_text.text: In the study, 463 families were identified (Table S3 ). Fig. S3 shows the species composition of the microbial communities at the family level. The most dominant family in the control belonged to P3OB-42, while the most dominant families in A belonged to norank_o__Chloroplast and unclassified_c__Alphaproteobacteria. After recovery from acclimation, Family_XII_o__Clostridiales exhibited the highest relative content, which differed significantly from the control (Tamhane's T2, p b .01). After exposure to high temperature stress (33°C), the most abundant bacteria in group RAHS were Phormidesmiaceae, while Vibrionaceae were most abundant in group HS, displaying higher content than all the other bacteria combined in that group. Comparisons of relative microbial counts at the family level in group C vs. A, C vs. RA, and HS vs. RAHS (Welch's ttest, p b .05) are shown in Fig. 3 . To gain further insight into the metabolic pathways involved in coral acclimation, we used PICRUSt to predict the bacterial function composition profiles based on 16S rRNA sequencing data in all treatment groups (Table S4 ). Statistical analysis revealed that the mean relative abundances of four functional categories differed significantly between the control and group RA, and that compared with the control group, metabolism and signal transduction metabolic pathways increased significantly in group RA (t-test, p b .05, Fig. S4 ). Seven metabolic pathways differed significantly between HS and RAHS (t-test, p b .05, Fig. S4 ).
body_text.section: Changes in coral-associated bacterial communities during thermal acclimation

body_text.text: Overall, 15 metatranscriptome libraries of A. pruinosa were sequenced to quantitatively compare coral gene expression profiles in the different treatment groups. In the analysis, 728,397,132 high-quality clean reads were filtered from 733,922,850 paired-end raw reads with 98.16% Q20 and 94.35% Q30 bases. Furthermore, de novo assembling yielded 116,897 unigenes. After assembly, functional information of genes and transcripts was obtained comprehensively, and annotations of the databases were counted (Table S5 , E-value: 1e-5). BLASTx top-hit species distribution of the 67,010 annotated unigenes exhibited highest homology to Symbiodiniaceae microadriaticum (40.57%), followed by A. digitifera (31.83%), S. pistillata (5.31%), and O. faveolata (4.52%) (Fig. S5) . Principal component analysis plots of unigene expression levels in the five treatment groups revealed that replicates were more highly correlated within treatment groups than between treatment groups (Fig. S6) .
body_text.section: Analysis of gene expression response during thermal acclimation

body_text.text: Expression levels of 30,074 coral host unigenes and 28,545 Symbiodiniaceae unigenes were quantitatively analysed by RSEM to obtain a quantitative index in terms of transcripts per million (TPM) ( Table S6 ). Analysis revealed 575 DEGs in the coral host between the control and group RA (FDR b 0.05), but no Symbiodiniaceae DEGs (Table S7). Further, 257 genes were significantly upregulated and 318 significantly downregulated in the coral host (FDR b 0.05). Fifteen enriched KEGG pathways were detected for the downregulated coral host genes (corrected p-value b.05), of which the nitrogen metabolism pathway was the most significantly downregulated (corrected pvalue = 7.89 × 10 −3 ) ( Table S8 , sheet Coral_CvsRA-down). Comparatively, no enriched KEGG pathway was detected for the upregulated coral host genes (Fig. 4, Table S8 ). Compared with group HS, 1933 and DEGs were detected in the coral host and Symbiodiniaceae of group RAHS, respectively. The former included 930 significantly upregulated and 1003 significantly downregulated genes (FDR b 0.05), whereas the latter contained only one significantly upregulated gene (FDR b 0.05, Table S7 ). The significantly upregulated coral genes were assigned to 2 significantly enriched pathways and the significantly downregulated coral genes were assigned to 16 significantly enriched pathways (corrected p-value b.05) (Table S8 , sheet Coral_HSvsRAHS-up and Coral_HSvsRAHS-down), while no enriched KEGG pathway was detected for the significantly upregulated Symbiodiniaceae gene (corrected p-value b.05). Among the encoded functional groups, the significantly enriched KEGG pathways were mainly associated with environmental disturbance response, such as immunity, disease resistance, apoptosis, and cell death (Fig. 5, Table S8 ). In the present study, 10 candidate genes were randomly selected to validate their expression patterns in the transcriptome data using qPCR (Fig. S7) . These genes exhibited similar expression changes by RNA-Seq and qPCR, which suggested that transcriptome data can reflect actual gene expression profiles.
body_text.section: Analysis of gene expression response during thermal acclimation

body_text.text: A large number of ecological investigations have demonstrated that corals exposed to thermal stress display higher heat tolerance in response to a second heat stress (Barker, 2018; Kenkel and Matz, 2016; Kirk et al., 2018) compared with unexposed corals. In the current study, a holistic approach was employed to comprehensively survey the responses of the three components of the A. pruinosa holobiont (the coral host, Symbiodiniaceae, and the bacterial community) to thermal acclimation.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: A second high temperature stress at 33°C is an effective assessment of acclimation efficiency (Middlebrook et al., 2008) . Here, the unacclimated A. pruinosa exhibited bleaching when exposed to elevated temperature, whereas the acclimated corals appeared to survive. Meanwhile, Symbiodiniaceae density and maximum quantum yield decreased significantly after heat stress, with acclimated corals exhibiting significantly higher levels than unacclimated corals. However, SOD and CAT activities in coral tissues increased significantly with high seawater temperature. Increased antioxidant enzyme activity is indicative of increased concentrations of reactive oxygen species (ROS) (Lesser et al., 1990) and reflects changes in oxygen concentrations. SOD and CAT activities in the coral host changed in response to the amount of oxygen photosynthetically generated by its algal symbionts. Increased enzymatic activity in corals at high seawater temperatures is well documented (Yakovleva et al., 2004) . Based on these findings, we postulate that unacclimated corals suffered more severe ROS damage than acclimated corals.
body_text.section: Thermal acclimation increased heat tolerance of A. pruinosa

body_text.text: RNA-seq analysis indicated that following the second heat stress, unacclimated corals launched stronger immune and cellular apoptotic responses than acclimated corals. Moreover, disease-related metabolic pathways were significantly enhanced in the former. This suggests that apoptosis and immune mechanisms are important coral host responses to temperature stress, as temperature stress also increases the risk of coral disease (Zhou et al., 2017a (Zhou et al., , 2017b Tang et al., 2018) . Furthermore, we found symbiotic bacterial abundance or composition differed significantly between the acclimated and unacclimated corals after exposure to the second temperature stress, and symbiotic microorganism diversity was reduced in the unacclimated corals. At the microbial level, reduction in α-diversity affects the ability of an individual to resist infection, absorb nutrients, and maintain the aggregate function of a healthy microbiome (Flanagan et al., 2007; Pollock et al., 2019) . On the macroscopic scale, decreased species diversity often leads to increased risk of sudden and potentially irreversible ecosystem collapse (Hooper et al., 2012; Ives and Carpenter, 2007; McCann, 2000) . According to the Anna Karenina principle (Zaneveld et al., 2017) , loss of microbial diversity may affect the overall biological resilience of corals. In addition to decreased α-diversity, there is evidence that stressors induce changes to coral microbiome β-diversity (Zaneveld et al., 2016; McDevitt-Irwin et al., 2017) . Corals exposed to heat stress and contact with macroalgae were shown to exhibit increased microbiome β-diversity (Zaneveld et al., 2016) . In other animals, increased in β-diversity in response to stress may indicate a destabilised microbiome (Moeller et al., 2013) , which also indicates the inability of the host to regulate its microbiome (Zaneveld et al., 2016) . Combining our transcriptome and symbiotic bacterial structure results, we speculate that heat stress will lead to increased levels of opportunistic bacteria such as Vibrio, which will inhibit the innate immune system of the coral (Vidal-Dupiol et al., 2014) and eventually break the stable coral and symbiotic bacteria relationship, leading to coral bleaching and death. Further, gene expression analysis indicated increased expression levels of genes involved in the Toll-like receptor (TLR) signalling pathway in unacclimated corals compared with acclimated corals. TLR signalling, which regulates the cnidarian microbiome by affecting antimicrobial peptide (AMP) secretion (Franzenburg et al., 2012) , is crucial for detection of microbes and initiation of immune response. It also indicates the presence of microbial stressors (Pollock et al., 2019) .
body_text.section: Thermal acclimation increased heat tolerance of A. pruinosa

body_text.text: 4.2. Thermal acclimation did not change the community structure of Symbiodiniaceae in A. pruinosa
body_text.section: Thermal acclimation increased heat tolerance of A. pruinosa

body_text.text: In the current study, the Symbiodiniaceae community in A. pruinosa was dominated by Cladocopium, especially by clade C1, which is consistent with Symbiodiniaceae from natural sea areas (Chen et al., 2019) . Particular symbiont genotypes may be an outcome of environmental selection and co-evolution (Lin et al., 2015; Thornhill et al., 2017) . While some hosts harbour two or more symbiont species simultaneously, many individual hosts associate with just one species of Symbiodiniaceae. Asexual division is, by far, the dominant reproductive mode of Symbiodiniaceae (Thornhill et al., 2017) , providing a substantial numerical advantage over conspecifics once a Symbiodiniaceae clonal lineage is established within a host (Thornhill et al., 2017) . On the other hand, the C1 genotype may be mainly attributed to the geographical location of Weizhou Island, which is located in the northern part of the South China Sea, within the high-latitude marginal coral reef areas of the Pacific Ocean (Yu, 2012) . Subclade C1 is a generalist symbiont type associated with most coral species in high-latitude marginal coral reef areas, such as Beibu Gulf, Daya Bay, and Leizhou Peninsula (China), Okinawa (Japan) and Jeju Island (South Korea) (Chen et al., 2019; De Palmas et al., 2015) .
body_text.section: Thermal acclimation increased heat tolerance of A. pruinosa

body_text.text: Interestingly, the Symbiodiniaceae community of A. pruinosa was relatively stable in the current study, regardless of the different temperature treatments. This persistent stable pattern was also observed in most colonies following the 1997-1998 bleaching event in the Bahamas and Florida Keys (Thornhill et al., 2006) . Under laboratory conditions, all Gorgonia ventalina sea fans harboured Breviolum throughout a heat-stress experiment, regardless of the temperature or length of exposure, and Symbiodiniaceae genera did not change when the sea fan host was infected with Aspergillus fungus (Kirk et al., 2005) . These examples illustrate stable associations between the coral host and symbiont, which is the most common situation encountered in all coral host species (Boulotte et al., 2016; Thornhill et al., 2006) .
body_text.section: Thermal acclimation increased heat tolerance of A. pruinosa

body_text.text: ITS is a widely used but highly problematic marker for Symbiodiniaceae studies. We acknowledge that the multiple-copy nature of the ITS2 region, which may result in pseudogenes or numerous low-abundant functional variants (LaJeunesse and Thornhill, 2011; Sampayo et al., 2009; Thornhill et al., 2007) , can affect the interpretation of next-generation sequencing data; an individual sequence does not necessarily represent an individual biological entity (Stat et al., 2011) . However, while not designed as a species delineation taxonomic approach, the data in this study reflect a robust comparative approach to assess genetic variation and new genetic variants in the assemblage of Symbiodiniaceae sequences throughout thermal acclimation (Boulotte et al., 2016) .
body_text.section: Thermal acclimation increased heat tolerance of A. pruinosa

body_text.text: Corals may harbour specific microbial communities for beneficial effect (Rohwer and Kelley, 2004) , and their microbial diversity may increase their adaptability to rapid change, potentially aiding acclimation of long-lived corals (Ziegler et al., 2017a (Ziegler et al., , 2017b . In this study, the microbial community reorganized after acclimation, exhibiting significantly increased abundance of unclassified_c__Alphaproteobacteria in the acclimated corals after exposure to early heat stress, and Family_XII_o__Clostridiales was the dominant bacteria in the acclimated corals after recovery. Unclassified_c__Alphaproteobacteria are the main bacteria that metabolise dimethylsulphoniopropionate (DMSP) (Raina et al., 2009) and constitute an extremely effective antioxidant system in the coral host and Symbiodiniaceae (Bourne et al., 2013; Sunda et al., 2002; Van Alstyne et al., 2006) . Combined with increased antioxidant enzymes activity, we propose that heat stress may promote the production of DMSP in coral hosts and Symbiodiniaceae (Gardner et al., 2017) , followed by increased abundance of unclassified_c__Alphaproteobacteria. The decomposition of DMSP results in increased sulphide concentration in the coral microecosystem (Kirkwood et al., 2010) , which leads to increased relative abundance of sulphur bacteria. In addition, we observed that the five most abundant bacteria in the acclimated corals post recovery were anaerobes or facultative anaerobes. This may be caused by decreased Symbiodiniaceae density and chlorophyll fluorescence upon heat stress, and a subsequent decrease in the coral microecological oxygen concentration (Buxton et al., 2009) , ultimately leading to increased relative abundance of anaerobes. Such highly structured microbiota composition suggests strong host-driven control of microbial partners (Zhou et al., 2017a (Zhou et al., , 2017b . Clostridia are a highly polyphyletic class of Firmicutes, of which some members are thermophilic bacteria that have been found in hot springs and deep-sea hydrothermal vents (Slobodkin et al., 2006) . There are also reports that their relative abundance increases when the host suffers heat stress (Marungruang et al., 2016) . At the same time, compared with the control, we observed a significant increase in microbial diversity in the acclimated corals post recovery. This might indicate that the coral host changes its main symbiont bacteria to a related species that performs better under certain conditions, thereby maintaining the physiological functions of the holobiont. Such subtle changes may represent an acclimatory response, which leads to a slightly altered microbiome that is better able to function under thermal stress conditions compared to the original bacterial community (Van Oppen and Blackall, 2019) . This further supported the hypothesis that the microbial community and coral heat tolerance are causally linked (Quigley et al., 2017; Van Oppen et al., 2018; Ziegler et al., 2017a Ziegler et al., , 2017b .
body_text.section: Thermal acclimation altered the diversity of symbiotic and dominant bacteria in A. pruinosa

body_text.text: To systematically explore the molecular mechanism of the coral host to regulate heat tolerance, the transcriptome libraries of A. pruinosa were sequenced and analysed. The annotations and differences in transcript abundance provided useful information for investigating the functions and expression patterns of unigenes involved in A. pruinosa acclimation. Transcriptome resilience, which may signal the physiological health and responsiveness of individuals to environmental stress (Seneca and Palumbi, 2015) , was indicated by a low number of DEGs and may be associated with the rapid return of coral gene expression to normal levels after thermal acclimation. In addition, within a certain range, a low number of DEGs could increase biological replication and help reduce false positive results (Zhou et al., 2017a (Zhou et al., , 2017b . To further understand the process of thermal acclimation response, we performed KEGG enrichment analysis of the downregulated genes. Fifteen KEGG metabolic pathways were significantly enriched, six of which were related to metabolism, with the nitrogen metabolism pathway being most significantly enriched. Coral reefs are generally found in areas with limited nutrient supply. In healthy corals, photosynthetically fixed carbon fulfils daily metabolic requirements and provides an energy reserve (Muscatine and Cernichiari, 1969) . In bleached corals, decreased net photosynthesis increases reliance on stored energy for survival and recovery (Rodrigues and Grottoli, 2007) . Therefore, we speculated that corals might maintain their energy supply by altering their nutritional patterns and reducing their metabolic rates during thermal acclimation, as reported for Porites compressa and Montipora capitatacorals (Rodrigues and Grottoli, 2007) . In addition, coral hosts and symbiotic bacteria have established mutually beneficial nutritional and metabolic complementation (Thompson et al., 2015) . Acclimated corals exhibited decreased relative abundance of nitrogen-fixing cyanobacteria compared with unacclimated corals, resulting in reduced nitrogen fixation, which may negatively impact the coral host's nitrogen metabolism (Lesser et al., 2004) . Thus, the metabolism increase suggested by metagenome analysis may act to complement the reduced coral host metabolism (Thompson et al., 2015) .
body_text.section: Thermal acclimation reduced coral host metabolism in A. pruinosa

body_text.text: In the current study, we highlighted the notion that the coralsymbiont association during thermal acclimation and the molecular mechanisms of increased tolerance induced by thermal acclimation are highly interdependent. Coral hosts, Symbiodiniaceae, and bacteria participated in the thermal acclimation of A. pruinosa. For the coral host, maintaining its energy supply by changing its nutritional patterns and reducing its metabolic rate during thermal acclimation may be a self-protective mechanism that could improve heat tolerance and plasticity in response to heat stress. For Symbiodiniaceae, Cladocopium was the dominant genus in A. pruinosa, which is the result of long-term natural selection and co-evolution. Corals maintain optimal symbiosis; thermal acclimation did not change the Symbiodiniaceae community structure, which further illustrated coral-symbiont stability. For symbiotic bacteria, microbial diversity may increase coral adaptability to rapid change. Here, Family_XII_o__Clostridiales became the dominant bacteria and increased microbial diversity may contribute to the higher thermal tolerance displayed by A. pruinosa. We hypothesise that thermal acclimation may increase coral thermal tolerance by slowing host metabolism, altering the dominant bacterial population, and increasing bacterial diversity. The processes and pathways that could potentially facilitate rapid acclimation in scleractinian coral are diverse, and considerable uncertainty surrounds their contribution to climate-change adaptation. The fate of coral reefs in the Anthropocene will largely depend on the rate at which scleractinian coral can adapt or acclimate to environmental change. Acute thermal acclimation could lead to increased thermal tolerance, providing potential opportunities for the coral to adapt to environmental changes. This has important implications for the evolution of the coral-symbiont association under global warming and may be critical in aiding the survival of coral reefs in a warmer future environment.
